That he does waigh too light: my greatest greefe,
Though little he do feele it, set downe sharpely.
Dispatch the most conuenient messenger,
When haply he shall heare that she is gone,
He will returne, and hope I may that shee
Hearing so much, will speede her foote againe,
Led hither by pure loue: which of them both
Is deerest to me, I haue no skill in sence
To make distinction: prouide this Messenger:
My heart is heauie, and mine age is weake,
Greefe would haue teares, and sorrow bids me speake.

div.head: [Act 3, Scene 5]
div.stage:
Enter old Widdow of Florence, her daughter, Violenta
and Mariana, with other
Citizens.

sp.speaker: Widdow.
sp.l: Nay come,
For if they do approach the Citty,
We shall loose all the sight.

sp.speaker: Diana.
sp.l: They say, the French Count has done
Most honourable seruice.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: It is reported,
That he has taken their great'st Commander,
And that with his owne hand he slew
The Dukes brother: we haue lost our labour,
They are gone a contrarie way: harke,
you may know by their Trumpets.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Come lets returne againe,
And suffice our selues with the report of it.
Well Diana, take heed of this French Earle,
The honor of a Maide is her name,
And no Legacie is so rich
As honestie.

sp.speaker: Widdow.
sp.l: I haue told my neighbour
How you haue beene solicited by a Gentleman
His Companion.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p:
I know that knaue, hang him, one Parolles,
a filthy Officer he is in those suggestions for the young
Earle, beware of them Diana; their promises, entise­
ments, oathes, tokens, and all these engines of lust, are
not the things they go vnder: many a maide hath beene
seduced by them, and the miserie is example, that so
terrible shewes in the wracke of maidenߛhood, cannot
for all that disswade succession, but that they are limed
with the twigges that threatens them. I hope I neede
not to aduise you further, but I hope your owne grace
will keepe you where you are, though there were no
further danger knowne, but the modestie which is so
lost.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: You shall not neede to feare me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
I hope so: looke here comes a pilgrim, I know
she will lye at my house, thither they send one another,
Ile question her. God saue you pilgrim, whether are
bound?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: To S. Iaques la grand.
Where do the Palmers lodge, I do beseech you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: At the S. Francis heere beside the Port.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Is this the way?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I marrie ist. Harke you, they come this way:
If you will tarrie holy Pilgrime
But till the troopes come by,
I will conduct you where you shall be lodg'd,
The rather for I thinke I know your hostesse
As ample as my selfe.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Is it your selfe?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: If you shall please so Pilgrime.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I thanke you, and will stay vpon your leisure.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: you came I thinke from France?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I did so.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Heere you shall see a Countriman of yours
That has done worthy seruice.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: His name I pray you?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: The Count Rossillion: know you such a one?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: But by the eare that heares most nobly of him:
His face I know not.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: What somere he is
He's brauely taken heere. He stole from France
As 'tis reported: for the King had married him
Against his liking. Thinke you it is so?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I surely meere the truth, I know his Lady.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: There is a Gentleman that serues the Count,
Reports but coursely of her.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: What's his name?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Monsieur Parrolles.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Oh I beleeue with him,
In argument of praise, or to the worth
Of the great Count himselfe, she is too meane
To haue her name repeated, all her deseruing
Is a reserued honestie, and that
I haue not heard examin'd.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Alas poore Ladie,
'Tis a hard bondage to become the wife
Of a detesting Lord.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I write good creature, wheresoere she is,
Her hart waighes sadly: this yong maid might do her
A shrewd turne if she pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: How do you meane?
May be the amorous Count solicites her
In the vnlawfull purpose.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: He does indeede,
And brokes with all that can in such a suite
Corrupt the tender honour of a Maide:
But she is arm'd for him, and keepes her guard
In honestest defence.

div.stage:
Drumme and Colours.
Enter Count Rossillion, Parrolles, and the whole Armie.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The goddes forbid else.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: So, now they come:
That is Anthonio the Dukes eldest sonne,
That Escalus.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Which is the Frenchman?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Hee,
That with the plume, 'tis a most gallant fellow,
I would he lou'd his wife: if he were honester
He were much goodlier. Is't not a handsom Gentleman

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I like him well.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: 'Tis pitty he is not honest: yonds that same knaue
That leades him to these places: were I his Ladie,
I would poison that vile Rascall.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Which is he?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p:
That Iacke an‑apes with scarfes. Why is hee
melancholly?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Perchance he's hurt i'th battaile.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Loose our drum? Well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
He's shrewdly vext at something. Looke he
has spyed vs.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Marrie hang you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And your curtesie, for a ring‑carrier.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
The troope is past: Come pilgrim, I wil bring
you, Where you shall host: Of inioyn'd penitents
There's foure or fiue, to great S. Iaques bound,
Alreadie at my house.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I humbly thanke you:
Please it this Matron, and this gentle Maide
To eate with vs to night, the charge and thanking
Shall be for me, and to requite you further,
I will bestow some precepts of this Virgin,
Worthy the note.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Wee'l take your offer kindly.

div.head: [Act 3, Scene 6]
div.stage:
Enter Count Rossillion and the Frenchmen,
as at first.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
Nay good my Lord put him too't: let him
haue his way.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
If your Lordshippe finde him not a Hilding,
hold me no more in your respect.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p: On my life my Lord a bubble.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Do you thinke I am so farre
Deceiued in him.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
Beleeue it my Lord, in mine owne direct
knowledge, without any malice, but to speake of him
as my kinsman, hee's a most notable Coward, an infi­
nite and endlesse Lyar, an hourely promise‑breaker, the
owner of no one good qualitie, worthy your Lordships
entertainment.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
It were fit you knew him, least reposing too
farre in his vertue which he hath not, he might at some
great and trustie businesse, in a maine daunger, fayle
you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
I would I knew in what particular action to try
him.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
None better then to let him fetch off his
drumme, which you heare him so confidently vnder­
take to do.

sp.speaker: C. E.
sp.p:
I with a troop of Florentines wil sodainly sur­
X2 prize
All's Well that Ends Well. prize him; such I will haue whom I am sure he knowes
not from the enemie: wee will binde and hoodwinke
him so, that he shall suppose no other but that he is car­
ried into the Leager of the aduersaries, when we bring
him to our owne tents: be but your Lordship present
at his examination, if he do not for the promise of his
life, and in the highest compulsion of base feare, offer to
betray you, and deliuer all the intelligence in his power
against you, and that with the diuine forfeite of his
soule vpon oath, neuer trust my iudgement in anie
thing.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
O for the loue of laughter, let him fetch his
drumme, he sayes he has a stratagem for't: when your
Lordship sees the bottome of this successe in't, and to
what mettle this counterfeyt lump of ours will be mel­
ted if you giue him not Iohn drummes entertainement,
your inclining cannot be remoued. Heere he comes.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
O for the loue of laughter hinder not the ho­
nor of his designe, let him fetch off his drumme in any
hand.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
How now Monsieur? This drumme sticks sore­
ly in your disposition.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p: A pox on't, let it go, 'tis but a drumme.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
But a drumme: Ist but a drumme? A drum so
lost. There was excellent command, to charge in with
our horse vpon our owne wings, and to rend our owne
souldiers.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
That was not to be blam'd in the command
of the seruice: it was a disaster of warre that Cæsar him
selfe could not haue preuented, if he had beene there to
command.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Well, wee cannot greatly condemne our suc­
cesse: some dishonor wee had in the losse of that drum,
but it is not to be recouered.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: It might haue beene recouered.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: It might, but it is not now.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
It is to be recouered, but that the merit of ser­
uice is sildome attributed to the true and exact perfor­
mer, I would haue that drumme or another, or hic ia­
cet.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Why if you haue a stomacke, too't Monsieur: if
you thinke your mysterie in stratagem, can bring this
instrument of honour againe into his natiue quarter, be
magnanimious in the enterprize and go on, I wil grace
the attempt for a worthy exploit: if you speede well in
it, the Duke shall both speake of it, and extend to you
what further becomes his greatnesse, euen to the vtmost
syllable of your worthinesse.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: By the hand of a souldier I will vndertake it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But you must not now slumber in it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Ile about it this euening, and I will presently
pen downe my dilemma's, encourage my selfe in my
certaintie, put my selfe into my mortall preparation:
and by midnight looke to heare further from me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
May I bee bold to acquaint his grace you are
gone about it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I know not what the successe wil be my Lord,
but the attempt I vow.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I know th'art valiant,
And to the possibility of thy souldiership,
Will subscribe for thee: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I loue not many words.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
No more then a fish loues water. Is not this a strange fellow my Lord, that so confidently seemes to
vndertake this businesse, which he knowes is not to be
done, damnes himselfe to do, & dares better be damnd
then to doo't.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
You do not know him my Lord as we doe,
certaine it is that he will steale himselfe into a mans fa­
uour, and for a weeke escape a great deale of discoue­
ries, but when you finde him out, you haue him euer af­
ter

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Why do you thinke he will make no deede at
all of this that so seriouslie hee dooes addresse himself
vnto?

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
None in the world, but returne with an in­
uention, and clap vpon you two or three probable lies:
but we haue almost imbost him, you shall see his fall to
night; for indeede he is not for your Lordshippes re­
spect.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
Weele make you some sport with the Foxe
ere we case him. He was first smoak'd by the old Lord
Lafew, when his disguise and he is parted, tell me what
a sprat you shall finde him, which you shall see this ve­
rie night.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.l: I must go looke my twigges,
He shall be caught.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Your brother he shall go along with me.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p: As't please your Lordship, Ile leaue you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Now wil I lead you to the house, and shew you
The Lasse I spoke of.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p: But you say she's honest.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: That's all the fault: I spoke with hir but once,
And found her wondrous cold, but I sent to her
By this same Coxcombe that we haue i'th winde
Tokens and Letters, which she did resend,
And this is all I haue done: She's a faire creature,
Will you go see her?

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p: With all my heart my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: If you misdoubt me that I am not shee,
I know not how I shall assure you further,
But I shall loose the grounds I worke vpon.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Though my estate be falne, I was well borne,
Nothing acquainted with these businesses,
And would not put my reputation now
In any staining act.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Nor would I wish you.
First giue me trust, the Count he is my husband,
And what to your sworne counsaile I haue spoken,
Is so from word to word: and then you cannot
By the good ayde that I of you shall borrow,
Erre in bestowing it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I should beleeue you,
For you haue shew'd me that which well approues
Y'are great in fortune.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Take this purse of Gold,
And let me buy your friendly helpe thus farre,
Which I will ouer‑pay, and pay againe

When I haue found it. The Count he woes your
daughter,
Layes downe his wanton siedge before her beautie,
Resolue to carrie her: let her in fine consent
As wee'l direct her how 'tis best to beare it:
Now his important blood will naught denie,
That shee'l demand: a ring the Countie weares,
That downward hath succeeded in his house
From sonne to sonne, some foure or fiue discents,
Since the first father wore it. This Ring he holds
In most rich choice: yet in his idle fire,
To buy his will, it would not seeme too deere,
How ere repented after.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Now I see the bottome of your purpose.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: You see it lawfull then, it is no more,
But that your daughter ere she seemes as wonne,
Desires this Ring; appoints him an encounter;
In fine, deliuers me to fill the time,
Her selfe most chastly absent: after
To marry her, Ile adde three thousand Crownes
To what is past already.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I haue yeelded:
Instruct my daughter how she shall perseuer,
That time and place with this deceite so lawfull
May proue coherent. Euery night he comes
With Musickes of all sorts, and songs compos'd
To her vnworthinesse: It nothing steeds vs
To chide him from our eeues, for he persists
As if his life lay on't.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Why then to night
Let vs assay our plot, which if it speed,
Is wicked meaning in a lawfull deede;
And lawfull meaning in a lawfull act,
Where both not sinne, and yet a sinfull fact.
But let's about it.

div.head: Actus Quartus.
[Act 4, Scene 1]
div.stage:
Enter one of the Frenchmen, with fiue or sixe other
souldiers in ambush.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord E.
sp.p:
He can come no other way but by this hedge
corner: when you sallie vpon him, speake what terrible
Language you will: though you vnderstand it not your
selues, no matter: for we must not seeme to vnderstand
him, vnlesse some one among vs, whom wee must pro­
duce for an Interpreter.

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.p: Good Captaine, let me be th' Interpreter.

sp.speaker: Lor. E.
sp.p:
Art not acquainted with him? knowes he not
thy voice?

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.p: No sir I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lo. E.
sp.p:
But what linsie wolsy hast thou to speake to vs
againe.

sp.speaker: 1. Sol.
sp.p: E'n such as you speake to me.

sp.speaker: Lo. E.
sp.p:
He must thinke vs some band of strangers, i'th
aduersaries entertainment. Now he hath a smacke of all
neighbouring Languages: therefore we must euery one
be a man of his owne fancie, not to know what we speak
one to another: so we seeme to know, is to know straight
our purpose: Choughs language, gabble enough, and
good enough. As for you interpreter, you must seeme
very politicke. But couch hoa, heere hee comes, to be­
guile two houres in a sleepe, and then to returne & swear
the lies he forges.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Ten a clocke: Within these three houres 'twill
be time enough to goe home. What shall I say I haue
done? It must bee a very plausiue inuention that carries
it. They beginne to smoake mee, and disgraces haue of
late, knock'd too often at my doore: I finde my tongue
is too foole‑hardie, but my heart hath the feare of Mars
before it, and of his creatures, not daring the reports of
my tongue.

sp.speaker: Lo. E.
sp.p:
This is the first truth that ere thine own tongue
was guiltie of.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
What the diuell should moue mee to vndertake
the recouerie of this drumme, being not ignorant of the
impossibility, and knowing I had no such purpose? I
must giue my selfe some hurts, and say I got them in ex­
ploit: yet slight ones will not carrie it. They will say,
came you off with so little? And great ones I dare not
giue, wherefore what's the instance. Tongue, I must put
you into a Butter‑womans mouth, and buy my selfe ano­
ther of Baiazeths Mule, if you prattle mee into these
perilles.

sp.speaker: Lo. E.
sp.p:
Is it possible he should know what hee is, and
be that he is.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I would the cutting of my garments wold serue
the turne, or the breaking of my Spanish sword.

sp.speaker: Lo. E.
sp.p: We cannot affoord you so.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Or the baring of my beard, and to say it was in
stratagem.

sp.speaker: Lo. E.
sp.p: 'Twould not do.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Or to drowne my cloathes, and say I was stript.

sp.speaker: Lo. E.
sp.p: Hardly serue.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Though I swore I leapt from the window of the
Citadell.

sp.speaker: Lo. E.
sp.p: How deepe?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Thirty fadome.

sp.speaker: Lo. E.
sp.p:
Three great oathes would scarse make that be
beleeued.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I would I had any drumme of the enemies, I
would sweare I recouer'd it.

sp.speaker: Lo. E.
sp.p: You shall heare one anon.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: A drumme now of the enemies.

sp.speaker: Lo. E.
sp.p: Throca movousus, cargo, cargo, cargo.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Cargo, cargo, cargo, villianda par corbo, cargo.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: O ransome, ransome,
Do not hide mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.p: Boskos thromuldo boskos.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I know you are the Muskos Regiment,
And I shall loose my life for want of language.
If there be heere German or Dane, Low Dutch,
Italian, or French, let him speake to me,
Ile discouer that, which shal vndo the Florentine.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
Boskos vauvado, I vnderstand thee, & can speake
thy tongue: Kerelybonto sir, betake thee to thy faith, for
seuenteene ponyards are at thy bosome.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Oh.

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.p:
Oh pray, pray, pray,
Manka reuania dulche.

sp.speaker: Lo. E.
sp.p: Oscorbidulchos voliuorco.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: The Generall is content to spare thee yet,
And hoodwinkt as thou art, will leade thee on
To gather from thee. Haply thou mayst informe
Something to saue thy life.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: O let me liue,
And all the secrets of our campe Ile shew,
Their force, their purposes: Nay, Ile speake that,
Which you will wonder at.

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.p: But wilt thou faithfully?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: If I do not, damne me.

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.l: Acordo linta.
Come on, thou are granted space.

sp.speaker: L.E.
sp.l: Go tell the Count Rossillion and my brother,

We haue caught the woodcocke, and will keepe him
(mufled,
Till we do heare from them.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: Captaine I will.

sp.speaker: L.E.
sp.p:
A will betray vs all vnto our selues,
Informe on that.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: So I will sir.

sp.speaker: L.E.
sp.p: Till then Ile keepe him darke and safely lockt.

div.head: [Act 4, Scene 2]
div.stage:
Enter Bertram, and the Maide called
Diana.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: They told me that your name was Fontybell.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: No my good Lord, Diana.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Titled Goddesse,
And worth it with addition: but faire soule,
In your fine frame hath loue no qualitie?
If the quicke fire of youth light not your minde,
You are no Maiden but a monument
When you are dead you should be such a one
As you are now: for you are cold and sterne,
And now you should be as your mother was
When your sweet selfe was got.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: She then was honest.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: So should you be.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: No:
My mother did but dutie, such (my Lord)
As you owe to your wife.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No more a'that:
I prethee do not striue against my vowes:
I was compell'd to her, but I loue thee
By loues owne sweet constraint, and will for euer
Do thee all rights of seruice.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I so you serue vs
Till we serue you: But when you haue our Roses,
You barely leaue our thornes to pricke our selues,
And mocke vs with our barenesse.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: How haue I sworne.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Tis not the many oathes that makes the truth,
But the plaine single vow, that is vow'd true:
What is not holie, that we sweare not by,
But take the high'st to witnesse: then pray you tell me,
If I should sweare by Ioues great attributes,
I lou'd you deerely, would you beleeue my oathes,
When I did loue you ill? This ha's no holding
To sweare by him whom I protest to loue
That I will worke against him. Therefore your oaths
Are words and poore conditions, but vnseal'd
At lest in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Change it, change it:
Be not so holy cruell: Loue is holie,
And my integritie ne're knew the crafts
That you do charge men with: Stand no more off,
But giue thy selfe vnto my sicke desires,
Who then recouers. Say thou art mine, and euer
My loue as it beginnes, shall so perseuer.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I see that men make rope's in such a scarre,
That wee'l forsake our selues. Giue me that Ring.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ile lend it thee my deere; but haue no power
To giue it from me.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Will you not my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: It is an honour longing to our house,
Bequeathed downe from manie Ancestors,
Which were the greatest obloquie i'th world,
In me to loose.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Mine Honors such a Ring,
My chastities the Iewell of our house,
Bequeathed downe from many Ancestors,
Which were the greatest obloquie i'th world,
In mee to loose. Thus your owne proper wisedome
Brings in the Champion honor on my part,
Against your vaine assault.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Heere, take my Ring,
My house, mine honor, yea my life be thine,
And Ile be bid by thee.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l:
When midnight comes, knocke at my cham­
ber window:
Ile order take, my mother shall not heare.
Now will I charge you in the band of truth,
When you haue conquer'd my yet maiden‑bed,
Remaine there but an houre, nor speake to mee:
My reasons are most strong, and you shall know them,
When backe againe this Ring shall be deliuer'd:
And on your finger in the night, Ile put
Another Ring, that what in time proceeds,
May token to the future, our past deeds.
Adieu till then, then faile not: you haue wonne
A wife of me, though there my hope be done.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: A heauen on earth I haue won by wooing thee.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l:
For which, liue long to thank both heauen & me,
You may so in the end.
My mother told me iust how he would woo,
As if she sate in's heart. She sayes, all men
Haue the like oathes: He had sworne to marrie me
When his wife's dead: therfore Ile lye with him
When I am buried. Since Frenchmen are so braide,
Marry that will, I liue and die a Maid:
Onely in this disguise, I think't no sinne,
To cosen him that would vniustly winne.

div.head: [Act 4, Scene 3]
div.stage:
Enter the two French Captaines, and some two or three
Souldiours.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p: You haue not giuen him his mothers letter.

sp.speaker: Cap.E.
sp.p:
I haue deliu'red it an houre since, there is som
thing in't that stings his nature: for on the reading it,
he chang'd almost into another man.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
He has much worthy blame laid vpon him,
for shaking off so good a wife, and so sweet a Lady.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
Especially, hee hath incurred the euerlasting
displeasure of the King, who had euen tun'd his bounty
to sing happinesse to him. I will tell you a thing, but
you shall let it dwell darkly with you.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
When you haue spoken it 'tis dead, and I am
the graue of it.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
Hee hath peruerted a young Gentlewoman
heere in Florence, of a most chaste renown, & this night
he fleshes his will in the spoyle of her honour: hee hath
giuen her his monumentall Ring, and thinkes himself
made in the vnchaste composition.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
Now God delay our rebellion as we are our
selues, what things are we.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
Meerely our owne traitours. And as in the
common course of all treasons, we still see them reueale
themselues, till they attaine to their abhorr'd ends: so
he that in this action contriues against his owne Nobi­
lity in his proper streame, ore‑flowes himselfe.

sp.speaker: Cap.G.
sp.p:
Is it not meant damnable in vs, to be Trum­
peters of our vnlawfull intents? We shall not then haue
his company to night?

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
Not till after midnight: for hee is dieted to
his houre.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
That approaches apace: I would gladly haue
him see his company anathomiz'd, that hee might take a
All's Well that Ends Well. a measure of his owne iudgements, wherein so curiously
he had set this counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
We will not meddle with him till he come;
for his presence must be the whip of the other.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
In the meane time, what heare you of these
Warres?

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p: I heare there is an ouerture of peace.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p: Nay, I assure you a peace concluded.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
What will Count Rossillion do then? Will he
trauaile higher, or returne againe into France?

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
I perceiue by this demand, you are not alto­
gether of his councell.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
Let it be forbid sir, so should I bee a great
deale of his act.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
Sir, his wife some two months since fledde
from his house, her pretence is a pilgrimage to Saint Ia­
ques le grand; which holy vndertaking, with most au­
stere sanctimonie she accomplisht: and there residing,
the tendernesse of her Nature, became as a prey to her
greefe: in fine, made a groane of her last breath, & now
she sings in heauen.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p: How is this iustified?

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
The stronger part of it by her owne Letters,
which makes her storie true, euen to the poynt of her
death: her death it selfe, which could not be her office
to say, is come: was faithfully confirm'd by the Rector
of the place.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p: Hath the Count all this intelligence?

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
I, and the particular confirmations, point
from point, to the full arming of the veritie.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
I am heartily sorrie that hee'l bee gladde of
this.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
How mightily sometimes, we make vs com­
forts of our losses.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
And how mightily some other times, wee
drowne our gaine in teares, the great dignitie that his
valour hath here acquir'd for him, shall at home be en­
countred with a shame as ample.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
The webbe of our life, is of a mingled yarne,
good and ill together: our vertues would bee proud, if
our faults whipt them not, and our crimes would dis­
paire if they were not cherish'd by our vertues.
How now? Where's your master?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
He met the Duke in the street sir, of whom hee
hath taken a solemne leaue: his Lordshippe will next
morning for France. The Duke hath offered him Let­
ters of commendations to the King.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
They shall bee no more then needfull there,
if they were more then they can commend.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
They cannot be too sweete for the Kings tart­
nesse, heere's his Lordship now. How now my Lord,
i'st not after midnight?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
I haue to night dispatch'd sixteene businesses, a
moneths length a peece, by an abstract of successe: I
haue congied with the Duke, done my adieu with his
neerest; buried a wife, mourn'd for her, writ to my La­
die mother, I am returning, entertain'd my Conuoy, &
betweene these maine parcels of dispatch, affected ma­
ny nicer needs: the last was the greatest, but that I haue
not ended yet.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
If the businesse bee of any difficulty, and this
morning your departure hence, it requires hast of your
Lordship.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
I meane the businesse is not ended, as fearing
to heare of it hereafter: but shall we haue this dialogue
betweene the Foole and the Soldiour. Come, bring
forth this counterfet module, ha's deceiu'd mee, like a
double‑meaning Prophesier.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
Bring him forth, ha's sate i'th stockes all night
poore gallant knaue.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
No matter, his heeles haue deseru'd it, in vsur­
ping his spurres so long. How does he carry himselfe?

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
I haue told your Lordship alreadie: The
stockes carrie him. But to answer you as you would be
vnderstood, hee weepes like a wench that had shed her
milke, he hath confest himselfe to Morgan, whom hee
supposes to be a Friar, frōfrom the time of his remembrance
to this very instant disaster of his setting i'th stockes:
and what thinke you he hath confest?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Nothing of me, ha's a?

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
His confession is taken, and it shall bee read 
to his face,
                                    if your Lordshippe be in't, as I beleeue you 
are,
                                    you must haue the patience to heare it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
A plague vpon him, muffeld; he can say nothing
of me: hush, hush.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p: Hoodman comes: Portotartarossa.

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.p:
He calles for the tortures, what will you say
without em.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I will confesse what I know without constraint,
If ye pinch me like a Pasty, I can say no more.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Bosko Chimurcho.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Boblibindo chicurmurco.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
You are a mercifull Generall: Our Generall
bids you answer to what I shall aske you out of a Note.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: And truly, as I hope to lieu.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
First demand of him, how many horse the Duke
is strong. What say you to that?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Fiue or sixe thousand, but very weake and vn­
seruiceable: the troopes are all scattered, and the Com­
manders verie poore rogues, vpon my reputation and
credit, and as I hope to liue.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Shall I set downe your answer so?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Do, Ile take the Sacrament on't, how & which
way you will: all's one to him.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What a past‑sauing slaue is this?

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
Y'are deceiu'd my Lord, this is Mounsieur
Parrolles the gallant militarist, that was his owne phrase
that had the whole theoricke of warre in the knot of his
scarfe, and the practise in the chape of his dagger.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
I will neuer trust a man againe, for keeping
his sword cleane, nor beleeue he can haue euerie thing
in him, by wearing his apparrell neatly.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Well, that's set downe.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Fiue or six thousand horse I sed, I will say true,
or thereabouts set downe, for Ile speake truth.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p: He's very neere the truth in this.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
But I con him no thankes for't in the nature he
deliuers it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Poore rogues, I pray you say.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Well, that's set downe.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l:
I humbly thanke you sir, a truth's a truth, the
Rogues are maruailous poore.

sp.speaker: Interp.
sp.p:
Demaund of him of what strength they are a
foot. What say you to that?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
By my troth sir, if I were to liue this present
houre, I will tell true. Let me see, Spurio a hundred & fiftie
All's Well, that Ends Well. fiftie, Sebastian so many, Corambus so many, Iaques so
many: Guiltian, Cosmo, Lodowicke, and Gratij, two hun­
dred fiftie each: Mine owne Company, Chitopher, Uau­
mond, Bentij, two hundred fiftie each: so that the muster
file, rotten and sound, vppon my life amounts not to fif­
teene thousand pole, halfe of the which, dare not shake
the snow from off their Cassockes, least they shake them­
selues to peeces.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What shall be done to him?

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
Nothing, but let him haue thankes. Demand
of him my condition: and what credite I haue with the
Duke.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
Well that's set downe: you shall demaund of
him, whether one Captaine Dumaine bee i'th Campe, a
Frenchman: what his reputation is with the Duke, what
his valour, honestie, and expertnesse in warres: or whe­
ther he thinkes it were not possible with well‑weighing
summes of gold to corrupt him to a reuolt. What say you
to this? What do you know of it?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I beseech you let me answer to the particular of
the intergatories. Demand them singly.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Do you know this Captaine Dumaine?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I know him, a was a Botchers Prentize in Paris,
from whence he was whipt for getting the Shrieues fool
with childe, a dumbe innocent that could not say him
nay.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Nay, by your leaue hold your hands, though I
know his braines are forfeite to the next tile that fals.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
Well, is this Captaine in the Duke of Florences
campe?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Vpon my knowledge he is, and lowsie.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
Nay looke not so vpon me: we shall heare of
your Lord anon.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: What is his reputation with the Duke?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
The Duke knowes him for no other, but a poore
Officer of mine, and writ to mee this other day, to turne
him out a'th band. I thinke I haue his Letter in my poc­
ket.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Marry we'll search.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
In good sadnesse I do not know, either it is there,
or it is vpon a file with the Dukes other Letters, in my
Tent.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Heere 'tis, heere's a paper, shall I reade it to you?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I do not know if it be it or no.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Our Interpreter do's it well.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p: Excellently.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Dian, the Counts a foole, and full of gold.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
That is not the Dukes letter sir: that is an ad­
uertisement to a proper maide in Florence, one Diana, to
take heede of the allurement of one Count Rossillion, a
foolish idle boy: but for all that very ruttish. I pray you
sir put it vp againe.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: Nay, Ile reade it first by your fauour.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
My meaning in't I protest was very honest in the
behalfe of the maid: for I knew the young Count to be a
dangerous and lasciuious boy, who is a whale to Virgi­
nity, and deuours vp all the fry it finds.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Damnable both‑sides rogue.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l:
Let. When he sweares oathes, bid him drop gold, and
take it:
After he scores, he neuer payes the score:
Halfe won is match well made, match and well make it,
He nere payes after‑debts, take it before,
And say a souldier (Dian) told thee this:
Men are to mell with, boyes are not to kis.
For count of this, the Counts a Foole I know it,
Who payes before, but not when he does owe it.
sp.p:
Thine as he vow'd to thee in thine eare,
Parolles.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
He shall be whipt through the Armie with this
rime in's forehead.

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p:
This is your deuoted friend sir, the manifold
Linguist, and the army‑potent souldier.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
I could endure any thing before but a Cat, and
now he's a Cat to me.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
I perceiue sir by your Generals lookes, wee shall
be faine to hang you.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
My life sir in any case: Not that I am afraide to
dye, but that my offences beeing many, I would repent
out the remainder of Nature. Let me liue sir in a dunge­
on, i'th stockes, or any where, so I may liue.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
Wee'le see what may bee done, so you confesse
freely: therefore once more to this Captaine Dumaine:
you haue answer'd to his reputation with the Duke, and
to his valour. What is his honestie?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
He will steale sir an Egge out of a Cloister: for
rapes and rauishments he paralels Nessus. Hee professes
not keeping of oaths, in breaking em he is stronger then
Hercules. He will lye sir, with such volubilitie, that you
would thinke truth were a foole: drunkennesse is his best
vertue, for he will be swine‑drunke, and in his sleepe he
does little harme, saue to his bed‑cloathes about him:
but they know his conditions, and lay him in straw. I
haue but little more to say sir of his honesty, he ha's eue­
rie thing that an honest man should not haue; what an
honest man should haue, he has nothing.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p: I begin to loue him for this.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
For this description of thine honestie? A pox
vpon him for me, he's more and more a Cat.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: What say you to his expertnesse in warre?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Faith sir, ha's led the drumme before the Eng­
lish Tragedians: to belye him I will not, and more of his
souldiership I know not, except in that Country, he had
the honour to be the Officer at a place there called Mile‑
end, to instruct for the doubling of files. I would doe the
man what honour I can, but of this I am not certaine.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
He hath out‑villain'd villanie so farre, that the
raritie redeemes him.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: A pox on him, he's a Cat still.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
His qualities being at this poore price, I neede
not to aske you, if Gold will corrupt him to reuolt.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Sir, for a Cardceue he will sell the fee‑simple of
his saluation, the inheritance of it, and cut th'intaile from
all remainders, and a perpetuall succession for it perpe­
tually.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: What's his Brother, the other Captain Dumain?

sp.speaker: Cap. E.
sp.p: Why do's he aske him of me?

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p: What's he?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
E'ne a Crow a'th same nest: not altogether so
great as the first in goodnesse, but greater a great deale in
euill. He excels his Brother for a coward, yet his Brother
is reputed one of the best that is. In a retreate hee out­
runnes any Lackey; marrie in comming on, hee ha's the
Crampe.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
If your life be saued, will you vndertake to betray
the Florentine.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I, and the Captaine of his horse, Count Rossillion.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
Ile whisper with the Generall, and knowe his
pleasure.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Ile no more drumming, a plague of all drummes,
onely to seeme to deserue well, and to beguile the suppo­sition
All's Well, that Ends Well.
sition of that lasciuious yong boy the Count, haue I run
into this danger: yet who would haue suspected an am­
bush where I was taken?

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
There is no remedy sir, but you must dye: the
Generall sayes, you that haue so traitorously discouerd
the secrets of your army, and made such pestifferous re­
ports of men very nobly held, can serue the world for
no honest vse: therefore you must dye. Come heades­
man, off with his head.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: O Lord sir let me liue, or let me see my death.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
That shall you, and take your leaue of all your
friends:
So, looke about you, know you any heere?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Good morrow noble Captaine.

sp.speaker: Lo. E.
sp.p: God blesse you Captaine Parolles.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p: God saue you noble Captaine.

sp.speaker: Lo. E.
sp.p:
Captain, what greeting will you to my Lord
Lafew? I am for France.

sp.speaker: Cap. G.
sp.p:
Good Captaine will you giue me a Copy of
the sonnet you writ to Diana in behalfe of the Count
Rossillion, and I were not a verie Coward, I'de compel
it of you, but far you well.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.p:
You are vndone Captaine all but your scarfe,
that has a knot on't yet.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Who cannot be crush'd with a plot?

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.p:
If you could finde out a Countrie where but
women were that had receiued so much shame, you
might begin an impudent Nation. Fare yee well sir, I
am for France too, we shall speake of you there.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Yet am I thankfull: if my heart were great
'Twould burst at this: Captaine Ile be no more,
But I will eate, and drinke, and sleepe as soft
As Captaine shall. Simply the thing I am
Shall make me liue: who knowes himselfe a braggart
Let him feare this; for it will come to passe,
That euery braggart shall be found an Asse.
Rust sword, coole blushes, and Parrolles liue
Safest in shame: being fool'd, by fool'rie thriue;
There's place and meanes for euery man aliue.
Ile after them.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l:
That you may well perceiue I haue not
wrong'd you,
One of the greatest in the Christian world
Shall be my suretie: for whose throne 'tis needful
Ere I can perfect mine intents, to kneele.
Time was, I did him a desired office
Deere almost as his life, which gratitude
Through flintie Tartars bosome would peepe forth,
And answer thankes. I duly am inform'd,
His grace is at Marcellæ, to which place
We haue conuenient conuoy: you must know
I am supposed dead, the Army breaking,
My husband hies him home, where heauen ayding,
And by the leaue of my good Lord the King,
Wee'l be before our welcome.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Gentle Madam,
You neuer had a seruant to whose trust
Your busines was more welcome.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Nor your Mistris
Euer a friend, whose thoughts more truly labour
To recompence your loue: Doubt not but heauen
Hath brought me vp to be your daughters dower,
As it hath fated her to be my motiue
And helper to a husband. But O strange men,
That can such sweet vse make of what they hate,
When sawcie trusting of the cosin'd thoughts
Defiles the pitchy night, so lust doth play
With what it loathes, for that which is away,
But more of this heereafter: you Diana,
Vnder my poore instructions yet must suffer
Something in my behalfe.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Let death and honestie
Go with your impositions, I am yours
Vpon your will to suffer.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Yet I pray you:
But with the word the time will bring on summer,
When Briars shall haue leaues as well as thornes,
And be as sweet as sharpe: we must away,
Our Wagon is prepar'd, and time reuiues vs,
All's well that ends well, still the fines the Crowne;
What ere the course, the end is the renowne.

div.head: [Act 4, Scene 5]
div.stage: Enter Clowne, old Lady, and Lafew.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
No, no, no, your sonne was misled with a snipt
taffata fellow there, whose villanous saffron wold haue
made all the vnbak'd and dowy youth of a nation in his
colour: your daughter‑in‑law had beene aliue at this
houre, and your sonne heere at home, more aduanc'd
by the King, then by that red‑tail'd humble Bee I speak
of.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
I would I had not knowne him, it was the death
of the most vertuous gentlewoman, that euer Nature
had praise for creating. If she had pertaken of my flesh
and cost mee the deerest groanes of a mother, I could
not haue owed her a more rooted loue.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Twas a good Lady, 'twas a good Lady. Wee
may picke a thousand sallets ere wee light on such ano­
ther hearbe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Indeed sir she was the sweete Margerom of the
sallet, or rather the hearbe of grace.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
They are not hearbes you knaue, they are nose­
hearbes.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p:
I am no great Nabuchadnezar sir, I haue not
much skill in grace.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Whether doest thou professe thy selfe, a knaue
or a foole?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
A foole sir at a womans seruice, and a knaue
at a mans.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Your distinction.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I would cousen the man of his wife, and do his
seruice.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: So you were a knaue at his seruice indeed.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
And I would giue his wife my bauble sir to doe
her seruice.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
I will subscribe for thee, thou art both knaue
and foole.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: At your seruice.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Why sir, if I cannot serue you, I can serue as
great a prince as you are.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Whose that, a Frenchman?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Faith sir a has an English maine, but his fisno­
mie is more hotter in France then there.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: What prince is that?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
The blacke prince sir, alias the prince of darke­
nesse, alias the diuell.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Hold thee there's my purse, I giue thee not this
to suggest thee from thy master thou talk'st off, serue
him still.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I am a woodland fellow sir, that alwaies loued
a great fire, and the master I speak of euer keeps a good
fire, but sure he is the Prince of the world, let his No­
bilitie remaine in's Court. I am for the house with the
narrow gate, which I take to be too little for pompe to
enter: some that humble themselues may, but the ma­
nie will be too chill and tender, and theyle bee for the
flowrie way that leads to the broad gate, and the great
fire.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Go thy waies, I begin to bee a wearie of thee,
and I tell thee so before, because I would not fall out
with thee. Go thy wayes, let my horses be wel look'd
too, without any trickes.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
If I put any trickes vpon em sir, they shall bee
Iades trickes, which are their owne right by the law of
Nature.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: A shrewd knaue and an vnhappie.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
So a is. My Lord that's gone made himselfe
much sport out of him, by his authoritie hee remaines
heere, which he thinkes is a pattent for his sawcinesse,
and indeede he has no pace, but runnes where he will.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
I like him well, 'tis not amisse: and I was about
to tell you, since I heard of the good Ladies death, and
that my Lord your sonne was vpon his returne home. I
moued the King my master to speake in the behalfe of
my daughter, which in the minoritie of them both, his
Maiestie out of a selfe gracious remembrance did first
propose, his Highnesse hath promis'd me to doe it, and
to stoppe vp the displeasure he hath conceiued against
your sonne, there is no fitter matter. How do's your
Ladyship like it?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
With verie much content my Lord, and I wish
it happily effected.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
His Highnesse comes post from Marcellus, of as
able bodie as when he number'd thirty, a will be heere
to morrow, or I am deceiu'd by him that in such intel­
ligence hath seldome fail'd.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
It reioyces me, that I hope I shall see him ere I
die. I haue letters that my sonne will be heere to night:
I shall beseech your Lordship to remaine with mee, till
they meete together.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Madam, I was thinking with what manners I
might safely be admitted.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p:
You neede but pleade your honourable priui­
ledge.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Ladie, of that I haue made a bold charter, but
I thanke my God, it holds yet.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
O Madam, yonders my Lord your sonne with
a patch of veluet on's face, whether there bee a scar vn­
der't or no, the Veluet knowes, but 'tis a goodly patch
of Veluet, his left cheeke is a cheeke of two pile and a
halfe, but his right cheeke is worne bare.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: A scarre nobly got,
Or a noble scarre, is a good liu'rie of honor,
So belike is that.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: But it is your carbinado'd face.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Let vs go see
your sonne I pray you, I long to talke
With the yong noble souldier.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p:
'Faith there's a dozen of em, with delicate
fine hats, and most courteous feathers, which bow the
head, and nod at euerie man.

div.head: Actus Quintus.
[Act 5, Scene 1]
div.stage:
Enter Hellen, Widdow, and Diana, with
two Attendants.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: But this exceeding posting day and night,
Must wear your spirits low, we cannot helpe it:
But since you haue made the daies and nights as one,
To weare your gentle limbes in my affayres,
Be bold you do so grow in my requitall,
As nothing can vnroote you. In happie time,
This man may helpe me to his Maiesties eare,
If he would spend his power. God saue you sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: And you.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Sir, I haue seene you in the Court of France.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I haue beene sometimes there.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I do presume sir, that you are not falne
From the report that goes vpon your goodnesse,
And therefore goaded with most sharpe occasions,
Which lay nice manners by, I put you to
The vse of your owne vertues, for the which
I shall continue thankefull.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: What's your will?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: That it will please you
To giue this poore petition to the King,
And ayde me with that store of power you haue
To come into his presence.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: The Kings not heere.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Not heere sir?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Not indeed,
He hence remou'd last night, and with more hast
Then is his vse.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Lord how we loose our paines.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: All's well that ends well yet,
Though time seeme so aduerse, and meanes vnfit:
I do beseech you, whither is he gone?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p:
Marrie as I take it to Rossillion,
Whither I am going.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I do beseech you sir,
Since you are like to see the King before me,
Commend the paper to his gracious hand,
Which I presume shall render you no blame,
But rather make you thanke your paines for it,
I will come after you with what good speede
Our meanes will make vs meanes.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: This Ile do for you.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
And you shall finde your selfe to be well thankt
what e're falles more. We must to horse againe, Go, go,
prouide.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Good Mr Lauatch giue my Lord Lafew this let­
ter, I haue ere now sir beene better knowne to you, when
I haue held familiaritie with fresher cloathes: but I am
now sir muddied in fortunes mood, and smell somewhat
strong of her strong displeasure.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Truely, Fortunes displeasure is but sluttish if it
smell so strongly as thou speak'st of: I will henceforth
eate no Fish of Fortunes butt'ring. Prethee alow the
winde.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Nay you neede not to stop your nose sir: I spake
but by a Metaphor.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Indeed sir, if your Metaphor stinke, I will stop
my nose, or against any mans Metaphor. Prethe get thee
further.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Pray you sir deliuer me this paper.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Foh, prethee stand away: a paper from fortunes
close‑stoole, to giue to a Nobleman. Looke heere he
comes himselfe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Heere is a purre of Fortunes sir, or of Fortunes
Cat, but not a Muscat, that ha's falne into the vncleane
fish‑pond of her displeasure, and as he sayes is muddied
withall. Pray you sir, vse the Carpe as you may, for he
ookes like a poore decayed, ingenious, foolish, rascally
naue. I doe pittie his distresse in my smiles of comfort,
nd leaue him to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
My Lord I am a man whom fortune hath cruel­
y scratch'd.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
And what would you haue me to doe? 'Tis too
ate to paire her nailes now. Wherein haue you played
he knaue with fortune that she should scratch you, who
f her selfe is a good Lady, and would not haue knaues
hriue long vnder? There's a Cardecue for you: Let the
ustices make you and fortune friends; I am for other
usinesse.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I beseech your honour to heare mee one single
word,

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
you begge a single peny more: Come you shall
ha't, saue your word.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: My name my good Lord is Parrolles.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
You begge more then word then. Cox my pas­
on, giue me your hand: How does your drumme?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
O my good Lord, you were the first that found
ee.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Was I insooth? And I was the first that lost thee.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
It lies in you my Lord to bring me in some grace
or you did bring me out.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Out vpon thee knaue, doest thou put vpon mee
t once both the office of God and the diuel: one brings
ee in grace, and the other brings thee out. The Kings
omming I know by his Trumpets. Sirrah, inquire fur­
er after me, I had talke of you last night, though you
re a foole and a knaue, you shall eate, go too, follow.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I praise God for you.

div.head: [Act 5, Scene 3]
div.stage:
Flourish. Enter King, old Lady, Lafew, the two French
Lords, with attendants.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p:
We lost a Iewell of her, and our esteeme
as made much poorer by it: but your sonne,
s mad in folly, lack'd the sence to know
er estimation home.

sp.speaker: Old La.
sp.p:
'Tis past my Liege,
nd I beseech your Maiestie to make it
aturall rebellion, done i'th blade of youth,
hen oyle and fire, too strong for reasons force,
re‑beares it, and burnes on.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: My honour'd Lady,
haue forgiuen and forgotten all,
Though my reuenges were high bent vpon him,
And watch'd the time to shoote.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: This I must say,
ut first I begge my pardon: the yong Lord
id to his Maiesty, his Mother, and his Ladie,
ffence of mighty note; but to himselfe
he greatest wrong of all. He lost a wife,
hose beauty did astonish the suruey
f richest eies: whose words all eares tooke captiue,
hose deere perfection, hearts that scorn'd to serue,
Humbly call'd Mistris.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Praising what is lost,
Makes the remembrance deere. Well, call him hither,
We are reconcil'd, and the first view shall kill
All repetition: Let him not aske our pardon,
The nature of his great offence is dead,
And deeper then obliuion, we do burie
Th' incensing reliques of it. Let him approach
A stranger, no offender; and informe him
So 'tis our will he should.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I shall my Liege.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What sayes he to your daughter,
Haue you spoke?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: All that he is, hath reference to your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p:
Then shall we haue a match. I haue letters sent
me, that sets him high in fame.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: He lookes well on't.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I am not a day of season,
For thou maist see a sun‑shine, and a haile
In me at once: But to the brightest beames
Distracted clouds giue way, so stand thou forth,
The time is faire againe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My high repented blames
Deere Soueraigne pardon to me.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: All is whole,
Not one word more of the consumed time,
Let's take the instant by the forward top:
For we are old, and on our quick'st decrees
Th' inaudible, and noiselesse foot of time
Steales, ere we can effect them. You remember
The daughter of this Lord?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Admiringly my Liege, at first
I stucke my choice vpon her, ere my heart
Durst make too bold a herauld of my tongue:
Where the impression of mine eye enfixing,
Contempt his scornfull Perspectiue did lend me,
Which warpt the line, of euerie other fauour,
Scorn'd a faire colour, or exprest it stolne,
Extended or contracted all proportions
To a most hideous obiect. Thence it came,
That she whom all men prais'd, and whom my selfe,
Since I haue lost, haue lou'd; was in mine eye
The dust that did offend it.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Well excus'd:
That thou didst loue her, strikes some scores away
From the great compt: but loue that comes too late,
Like a remorsefull pardon slowly carried
To the great sender, turnes a sowre offence,
Crying, that's good that's gone: Our rash faults,
Make triuiall price of serious things we haue,
Not knowing them, vntill we know their graue.
Oft our displeasures to our selues vniust,
Destroy our friends, and after weepe their dust:
Our owne loue waking, cries to see what's don,edone,
While shamefull hate sleepes out the afternoone.
Be this sweet Helens knell, and now forget her.
Send forth your amorous token for faire Maudlin,
The maine consents are had, and heere wee'l stay
To see our widdowers second marriage day:
Which better then the first, O deere heauen blesse,
Or, ere they meete in me, O Nature cesse.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Come on my sonne, in whom my houses name
Must be digested: giue a fauour from you
To sparkle in the spirits of my daughter,
That she may quickly come. By my old beard,
And eu'rie haire that's on't, Helen that's dead
Was a sweet creature: such a ring as this,
The last that ere I tooke her leaue at Court,
I saw vpon her finger.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Hers it was not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now pray you let me see it. For mine eye,
While I was speaking, oft was fasten'd too't:
This Ring was mine, and when I gaue it Hellen,
I bad her if her fortunes euer stoode
Necessitied to helpe, that by this token
I would releeue her. Had you that craft to reaue her
Of what should stead her most?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My gracious Soueraigne,
How ere it pleases you to take it so,
The ring was neuer hers.

sp.speaker: Old La.
sp.l: Sonne, on my life
I haue seene her weare it, and she reckon'd it
At her liues rate.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: I am sure I saw her weare it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You are deceiu'd my Lord, she neuer saw it:
In Florence was it from a casement throwne mee,
Wrap'd in a paper, which contain'd the name
Of her that threw it: Noble she was, and thought
I stood ingag'd, but when I had subscrib'd
To mine owne fortune, and inform'd her fully,
I could not answer in that course of Honour
As she had made the ouerture, she ceast
In heauie satisfaction, and would neuer
Receiue the Ring againe.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Platus himselfe,
That knowes the tinct and multiplying med'cine,
Hath not in natures mysterie more science,
Then I haue in this Ring. 'Twas mine, 'twas Helens,
Who euer gaue it you: then if you know
That you are well acquainted with your selfe,
Confesse 'twas hers, and by what rough enforcement
You got it from her. She call'd the Saints to suretie,
That she would neuer put it from her finger,
Vnlesse she gaue it to your selfe in bed,
Where you haue neuer come: or sent it vs
Vpon her great disaster.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: She neuer saw it.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thou speak'st it falsely: as I loue mine Honor,
And mak'st connecturall feares to come into me,
Which I would faine shut out, if it should proue
That thou art so inhumane, 'twill not proue so:
And yet I know not, thou didst hate her deadly,
And she is dead, which nothing but to close
Her eyes my selfe, could win me to beleeue,
More then to see this Ring. Take him away,
My fore‑past proofes, how ere the matter fall
Shall taze my feares of little vanitie,
Hauing vainly fear'd too little. Away with him,
Wee'l sift this matter further.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: If you shall proue
This Ring was euer hers, you shall as easie
Proue that I husbanded her bed in Florence,
Where yet she neuer was.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I am wrap'd in dismall thinkings.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Gracious Soueraigne.
Whether I haue beene too blame or no, I know not,
Here's a petition from a Florentine,
Who hath for foure or fiue remoues come short,
To tender it her selfe. I vndertooke it,
Vanquish'd thereto by the faire grace and speech
Of the poore suppliant, who by this I know
Is heere attending: her businesse lookes in her
With an importing visage, and she told me
In a sweet verball breefe, it did concerne
Your Highnesse with her selfe.
sp.p: A Letter.

Upon his many protestations to marrie mee when his wife was
dead, I blush to say it, he wonne me. Now is the Count Ros­
sillion a Widdower, his vowes are forfeited to mee, and my
honors payed to him. Hee stole from Florence, taking no
leaue, and I follow him to his Countrey for Iustice: Grant
it me, O King, in you it best lies, otherwise a seducer flou­
rishes, and a poore Maid is vndone.
Diana Capilet.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
I will buy me a sonne in Law in a faire, and toule
for this. Ile none of him.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: The heauens haue thought well on thee Lafew,
To bring forth this discou'rie, seeke these sutors:
Go speedily, and bring againe the Count.
sp.p: I am a‑feard the life of Hellen (Ladie)
Was fowly snatcht.

sp.speaker: Old La.
sp.p: Now iustice on the doers.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I wonder sir, sir, wiues are monsters to you,
And that you flye them as you sweare them Lordship,
Yet you desire to marry. What woman's that?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I am my Lord a wretched Florentine,
Deriued from the ancient Capilet,
My suite as I do vnderstand you know,
And therefore know how farre I may be pittied.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I am her Mother sir, whose age and honour
Both suffer vnder this complaint we bring,
And both shall cease, without your remedie.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Come hether Count, do you know these Wo­
men?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My Lord, I neither can nor will denie,
But that I know them, do they charge me further?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Why do you looke so strange vpon your wife?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: She's none of mine my Lord.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: If you shall marrie
You giue away this hand, and that is mine,
You giue away heauens vowes, and those are mine:
You giue away my selfe, which is knowne mine:
For I by vow am so embodied yours,
That she which marries you, must marrie me,
Either both or none.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Your reputation comes too short for my daugh­
ter, you are no husband for her.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My Lord, this is a fond and desp'rate creature,
Whom sometime I haue laugh'd with: Let your highnes
Lay a more noble thought vpon mine honour,
Then for to thinke that I would sinke it heere.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Sir for my thoughts, you haue them il to friend,
Till your deeds gaine them fairer: proue your honor,
Then in my thought it lies.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Good my Lord,
Aske him vpon his oath, if hee do's thinke
He had not my virginity.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: What saist thou to her?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: She's impudent my Lord,
And was a common gamester to the Campe.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: He do's me wrong my Lord: If I were so,
He might haue bought me at a common price.
o not beleeue him. O behold this Ring,
hose high respect and rich validitie
id lacke a Paralell: yet for all that
e gaue it to a Commoner a'th Campe
I be one.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: He blushes, and 'tis hit:
f sixe preceding Ancestors that Iemme
>onfer'd by testament to'th sequent issue
ath it beene owed and worne. This is his wife,
hat Ring's a thousand proofes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Me thought you saide
ou saw one heere in Court could witnesse it.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I did my Lord, but loath am to produce
o bad an instrument, his names Parrolles.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: I saw the man to day, if man he bee.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Finde him, and bring him hether.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: What of him:
e's quoted for a most perfidious slaue
ith all the spots a'th world, taxt and debosh'd,
hose nature sickens: but to speake a truth,
m I, or that or this for what he'l vtter,
hat will speake any thing.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: She hath that Ring of yours.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I thinke she has; certaine it is I lyk'd her,
nd boorded her i'th wanton way of youth:
he knew her distance, and did angle for mee,
adding my eagernesse with her restraint,
s all impediments in fancies course
re motiues of more fancie, and in fine,
er insuite comming with her moderne grace,
ubdu'd me to her rate, she got the Ring,
nd I had that which any inferiour might
t Market price haue bought.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I must be patient:
ou that haue turn'd off a first so noble wife,
May iustly dyet me. I pray you yet,
Since you lacke vertue, I will loose a husband)
end for your Ring, I will returne it home,
nd giue me mine againe.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I haue it not.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: What Ring was yours I pray you?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Sir much like the same vpon your finger.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Know you this Ring, this Ring was his of late.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: And this was it I gaue him being a bed.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p:
The story then goes false, you threw it him
ut of a Casement.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: I haue spoke the truth. Enter Parolles.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: My Lord, I do confesse the ring was hers.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: You boggle shrewdly, euery feather starts you:
s this the man you speake of?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: I, my Lord

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Tell me sirrah, but tell me true I charge you,
Not fearing the displeasure of your master:
Which on your iust proceeding, Ile keepe off,
By him and by this woman heere, what know you?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
So please your Maiesty, my master hath bin an
honourable Gentleman. Trickes hee hath had in him,
which Gentlemen haue.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p:
Come, come, to'th' purpose: Did hee loue this
woman?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Faith sir he did loue her, but how.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: How I pray you?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: He did loue her sir, as a Gent. loues a Woman.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: He lou'd her sir, and lou'd her not.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p:
As thou art a knaue and no knaue, what an equi­
uocall Companion is this?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I am a poore man, and at your Maiesties com­
mand.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Hee's a good drumme my Lord, but a naughtie
Orator.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Do you know he promist me marriage?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Faith I know more then Ile speake.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: But wilt thou not speake all thou know'st?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Yes so please your Maiesty: I did goe betweene
them as I said, but more then that he loued her, for in­
deede he was madde for her, and talkt of Sathan, and of
Limbo, and of Furies, and I know not what: yet I was in
that credit with them at that time, that I knewe of their
going to bed, and of other motions, as promising her
marriage, and things which would deriue mee ill will to
speake of, therefore I will not speake what I know.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p:
Thou hast spoken all alreadie, vnlesse thou canst
say they are maried, but thou art too fine in thy euidence,
therefore stand aside. This Ring you say was yours.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: I my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Where did you buy it? Or who gaue it you?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: It was not giuen me, nor I did not buy it.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Who lent it you?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: It was not lent me neither.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Where did you finde it then?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: I found it not.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: If it were yours by none of all these wayes,
How could you giue it him?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: I neuer gaue it him.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
This womans an easie gloue my Lord, she goes
off and on at pleasure.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: This Ring was mine, I gaue it his first wife.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: It might be yours or hers for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Take her away, I do not like her now,
To prison with her: and away with him,
Vnlesse thou telst me where thou hadst this Ring,
Thou diest within this houre.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Ile neuer tell you.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Take her away.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Ile put in baile my liedge.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: I thinke thee now some common Customer.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: By Ioue if euer I knew man 'twas you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Wherefore hast thou accusde him al this while.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Because he's guiltie, and he is not guilty:
He knowes I am no Maid, and hee'l sweare too't:
Ile sweare I am a Maid, and he knowes not.
Great King I am no strumpet, by my life,
I am either Maid, or else this old mans wife.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: She does abuse our eares, to prison with her.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Good mother fetch my bayle. Stay Royall sir,
The Ieweller that owes the Ring is sent for,
And he shall surety me. But for this Lord,
Who hath abus'd me as he knowes himselfe,
Though yet he neuer harm'd me, heere I quit him.
He knowes himselfe my bed he hath defil'd,
And at that time he got his wife with childe:
Dead though she be, she feeles her yong one kicke:
So there's my riddle, one that's dead is quicke,
And now behold the meaning.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Is there no exorcist
Beguiles the truer Office of mine eyes?
Is't reall that I see?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: No my good Lord,
sp.l: 'Tis but the shadow of a wife you see,
The name, and not the thing.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Both, both, O pardon.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Oh my good Lord, when I was like this Maid,
I found you wondrous kinde, there is your Ring,
And looke you, heeres your letter: this it sayes,
When from my finger you can get this Ring,
And is by me with childe, &c. This is done,
Will you be mine now you are doubly wonne?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: If she my Liege can make me know this clearly,
Ile loue her dearely, euer, euer dearly.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: If it appeare not plaine, and proue vntrue,
Deadly diuorce step betweene me and you.
O my deere mother do I see you liuing?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Mine eyes smell Onions, I shall weepe anon:
Good Tom Drumme lend me a handkercher.

So I thanke thee, waite on me home, Ile make sport with
thee: Let thy curtsies alone, they are scuruy ones.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let vs from point to point this storie know,
To make the euen truth in pleasure flow:
If thou beest yet a fresh vncropped flower,
Choose thou thy husband, and Ile pay thy dower.
For I can guesse, that by thy honest ayde,
Thou keptst a wife her selfe, thy selfe a Maide.
Of that and all the progresse more and lesse,
Resoluedly more leasure shall expresse:
All yet seemes well, and if it end so meete,
The bitter past, more welcome is the sweet.
THe Kings a Begger, now the Play is done,
All is well ended, if this suite be wonne,
That you expresse Content: which we will pay,
With strife to please you, day exceeding day:
Ours be your patience then, and yours our parts,
Your gentle hands lend vs, and take our hearts.
